001package io.github.ai4ci.flow.output;
002
003import java.io.Closeable;
004import java.io.File;
005import java.io.IOException;
006import java.util.stream.Stream;
007
008/**
009 * Interface for writing output data to a destination (e.g. file, database).
010 * Implementations must be thread safe and support non blocking export of data
011 * records, allowing for efficient handoff of data from the simulation thread to
012 * a separate consumer thread that handles the actual writing to disk. The setup
013 * method is called once to initialise the output destination and any necessary
014 * resources, while the export method can be called multiple times to write
015 * individual records. The flush and close methods allow for proper resource
016 * management and finalization of the output. The isWaiting and join methods
017 * provide mechanisms for monitoring the state of the consumer thread and
018 * ensuring that all data has been written before shutting down. The report
019 * method can be used to provide status updates or performance metrics about the
020 * writing process.
021 *
022 * @param <X> the type of data records that this OutputWriter can write, which
023 *            must implement the Writeable interface
024 * @author Rob Challen
025 */
026public interface OutputWriter<X extends io.github.ai4ci.flow.output.OutputWriter.Writeable>
027                extends Closeable {
028
029        /**
030         * Marker interface for data records that can be written by an OutputWriter.
031         * Implementing classes should define the structure of the data to be
032         * exported and may include methods for serialization or formatting of the
033         * data as needed by specific OutputWriter implementations (e.g. CSV
034         * formatting, database mapping). This interface serves as a common type for
035         * all data records that can be handled by Output Writers, ensuring type
036         * safety and consistency across different output formats and destinations.
037         *
038         */
039        public static interface Writeable {
040//              String header();
041//              String row();
042        }
043
044        /**
045         * Close the output writer and release any resources associated with it. This
046         * method should ensure that all pending data is flushed to the output
047         * destination before closing, and that any threads or resources used for
048         * writing are properly terminated. Implementations should handle any
049         * necessary cleanup to prevent resource leaks and ensure that the output
050         * destination is left in a consistent state.
051         */
052        @Override
053        void close();
054
055        /**
056         * Default method to export a stream of data records. This method iterates
057         * over the provided stream and calls the export method for each individual
058         * record. Implementations can override this method if they have specific
059         * optimizations for handling batches of records, but the default
060         * implementation provides a simple way to export multiple records without
061         * requiring additional logic in the consumer code.
062         *
063         * @param supply a Stream of data records to be exported, where each record
064         *               is of type X that implements Writeable
065         */
066        default void export(Stream<X> supply) {
067                supply.forEach(this::export);
068        }
069
070        /**
071         * A non blocking thread safe export, allowing very quick handing off of a
072         * data export data class to whatever (single) thread that is going to write
073         * it to disk.
074         *
075         * @param single a single data record of type X that implements Writeable to
076         *               be exported; this method should return quickly and not block
077         *               the calling thread, allowing for efficient handoff to the
078         *               consumer thread that will handle the actual writing to the
079         *               output destination
080         *
081         */
082        void export(X single);
083
084        /**
085         * Flush any buffered data to the output destination. This method should
086         * ensure that all data that has been handed off for writing is actually
087         * written to disk, and that any resources used for buffering are properly
088         * managed. Implementations should handle any necessary synchronization to
089         * ensure thread safety during the flush operation.
090         */
091        void flush();
092
093        /**
094         * Check if the consumer thread is currently waiting for data to be exported.
095         * This method can be used to monitor the state of the output writer and
096         * determine if it is idle or actively processing data. Implementations
097         * should provide a thread-safe way to check this state, allowing for
098         * coordination between the producer and consumer threads.
099         *
100         * @return true if the consumer thread is waiting for data, false otherwise
101         */
102        boolean isWaiting();
103
104        /**
105         * Wait for the consumer thread to finish processing all pending data and
106         * complete any ongoing write operations. This method should block until the
107         * consumer thread has finished writing all data to the output destination,
108         * ensuring that all exports are completed before proceeding with any
109         * shutdown or cleanup operations. Implementations should handle any
110         * necessary synchronization to ensure that this method works correctly in a
111         * multi-threaded environment.
112         *
113         * @throws InterruptedException if the current thread is interrupted while
114         *                              waiting for the consumer thread to finish
115         */
116        void join() throws InterruptedException;
117
118        /**
119         * Provide a status report or performance metrics about the writing process.
120         * This method can be used to return information about the current state of
121         * the output writer, such as the number of records written, the time taken
122         * for recent exports, or any errors encountered during writing.
123         * Implementations can customize this method to provide relevant information
124         * based on the specific output format and destination being used.
125         *
126         * @return a String containing the status report or performance metrics about
127         *         the writing process
128         */
129        String report();
130
131        /**
132         * Called once to setup an output destination and the consumer thread that
133         * writes data to it, (including buffer sizes if needed). As part of
134         * initialising this might write the headers for CSV files for example, or
135         * create the DuckDB table.
136         *
137         * @param type the Class object representing the type of data records that
138         *             will be written, used for reflection or type-specific setup
139         * @param file the File object representing the output destination (e.g. file
140         *             path) where data will be written
141         * @param size an integer representing the buffer size or batch size for
142         *             writing data, which can be used to optimize performance based
143         *             on the expected volume of data
144         * @throws IOException if an I/O error occurs during setup, such as issues
145         *                     with file permissions, disk space, or other problems
146         *                     that prevent the output destination from being
147         *                     properly initialized
148         *
149         */
150        void setup(Class<X> type, File file, int size) throws IOException;
151
152}
